- Prefer Julia standard libraries, avoid new packages unless explicitly requested.

# Task

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

In this task, we are asked to write a function `clean_column` that cleans the given column name. Here is how I would approach this problem in Julia:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
clean_name = lowercase(stripwhitespace(replace(col, "[ -]", "_")))
return clean_name
end
```
In the function `clean_column`, we are using the following Julia syntax:
- `lowercase(string)`: This function converts the input string to lowercase. It takes a single argument which is a string and returns a new string with all characters in lowercase.
- `stripwhitespace(string)`: This function removes any leading or trailing whitespaces from the input string. It takes a single argument which is a string and returns a new string with no leading or trailing whitespaces.
- `replace(string, pattern, replacement)`: This function replaces all occurrences of the specified pattern in the input string with the specified replacement string. It takes three arguments - `string`, `pattern`, and `replacement` - where `string` is the input string, `pattern` is a regular expression pattern to match, and `replacement` is the new string that will replace all matched patterns.

This function should meet the requirements of the problem by properly cleaning the column name according to the specified instructions.
